questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation reports a decrease in fetal movements over the past few days. Which of the following complications is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polyhydramnios

Explanation:

Polyhydramnios: Excessive amniotic fluid, is not typically associated with post-dated pregnancies. It is commonly seen in maternal diabetes, fetal anomalies, or infections.

Adverse Maternal and Perinatal Outcomes Associated with Post-term Pregnancy:

Maternal

Perinatal

Fetal macrosomia:(Option A)

 

Is a common complication of post-dated pregnancies due to the extended period of fetal growth.

Stillbirth

Oligohydramnios:

(Option B)

Reduced amniotic fluid, because the placenta becomes less efficient at maintaining amniotic fluid levels as it ages.

Post-maturity syndrome

Pre-eclampsia

Meconium aspiration syndrome(Option D):

The fetus is more likely to pass meconium into the amniotic fluid, which can be inhaled into the lungs during birth.

Postpartum hemorrhagic

Hypoxic ischemia encephalopathy

Labour dystocia

Birth injuries

Perineal lacerations

Childhood obesity

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to assess premature rupture of the membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bubble test

Explanation:

PROM diagnosis:

Diagnostic Method

Description

Speculum Examination

(Option A)

Aseptic inspection to observe fluid escaping through the cervix

Nitrazine Paper Test

(Option C)

pH indicator paper; turns blue (pH >6), indicating amniotic fluid (AF)

Fern Test (Ferning Pattern)

Microscopic examination of vaginal fluid smear for a characteristic fern-like pattern

Nile Blue Sulfate Stain

Stains exfoliated cells from fetal sebaceous glands; orange-blue colour indicates AF

AmniSure Rapid Immunoassay

Rapid test to detect specific proteins in vaginal fluid indicative of AF

Ultrasonography

(Option B)

Used to visualise amniotic fluid levels around the fetus; supports diagnosis and assesses fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation presents to the labor with complaints of decreased fetal movements. The urine protein on dipstick is negative. USG reveals a small for gestational age fetus in cephalic presentation, with AFI-5 cm, placenta is fundal. All of the following are done in managing this patient except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Immediate cesarean section

Explanation:

Initiation of fetal surveillance should be done beginning at 41 weeks of gestation.

  • Fetal surveillance (Nonstress test, Amniotic fluid volume estimation, Biophysical profile, Doppler velocimetry study)(Option B)

Induction of labor: (Option C)

  • Cervix ripe: Stripping of membranes → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.
  • Cervix unripe: Vaginal administration of PGE2 gel (6 hourly) → Cervix ripe → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.

Unfavourable cervix and cephalopelvic disproportion, if present, prompt immediate cesarean delivery(C-Section is done in obstetric conditions).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician at 41 weeks and 3 days of gestation. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, with normal fetal growth and no signs of preeclampsia or gestational diabetes. She reports feeling well; fetal movements are still noticeable but slightly reduced. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The ultrasound reveals normal amniotic fluid levels.

What is the most appropriate next step in managing this uncomplicated post-dated pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Perform NST

Explanation:

Management of uncomplicated post-dated pregnancy:

Step 1: Ensure Fetal Maturity

  • Fetal surveillance (Nonstress test, Amniotic fluid volume estimation, Biophysical profile, Doppler velocimetry study)

Step 2: Categorize the Case

Uncomplicated:

  • Induction (7-10 days)
  • Cervix ripe:

Stripping of membranes → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.

  • Cervix unripe:

Vaginal administration of PGE2 gel (6 hourly) → Cervix ripe → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.

Immediate induction of labour (Option A): Immediate induction may not be necessary given the absence of complications and reassuring fetal status.

Elective cesarean section(Option C): An elective cesarean section is not indicated for an uncomplicated post-dated pregnancy unless there are other clinical indications, such as fetal distress for ailed induction.

Administration of corticosteroids(Option D): Corticosteroids accelerate fetal lung maturity in preterm pregnancies, not post-dated pregnancies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 42 weeks of gestation with labour pain. An ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios and a large-for-gestational-age fetus. The newborn is delivered with dry, peeling skin weighing 4kg. What is the most likely diagnosis for this newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Post-maturity syndrome

Explanation:

Post-maturity syndrome :

The syndrome complicates 10 - 20% of pregnancies at 42 completed weeks. associated oligohydramnios raises the likelihood of postmaturity syndrome in the fetus. It is attricuted to placental senescence (ageing) & limited placental capacity. Associated skin changes follow loss of protective effects of vernix caseosa.

  • The postmature newborn has typical features that include dry and peeling skin, prominent skin wrinkling (typically over palms & soles), overgrown nails.
  • The post-term fetus continues to gain weight and thus be unusually large at birth; has a long & thin body that suggests wasting
  • This suggests that the placental function is not severely compromised.
  • They show advanced maturity can be seen in the neonate; open-eyed, unusually alert, and appears old & worried.

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)(Option A): While this condition might be considered, the baby's large size and other specific characteristics (dry, peeling skin, overgrown nails) disqualify it as IUGR.

Neonatal sepsis(Option C): Presents with signs of infection such as fever, lethargy, poor feeding, and respiratory distress. The described findings do not align with neonatal sepsis.

Congenital hypothyroidism( Option D): Can cause poor growth and development but does not typically present with the acute signs described (dry, peeling skin, overgrown nails) .

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in post-term pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Small for gestational age

Explanation:

Post-term pregnancy, which refers to a pregnancy that extends beyond 42 weeks, is associated with several complications. Small for gestational age is seen in cases of uteroplacental insufficiency. The post-term fetus continues to gain weight and thus be unusually large at birth.

Oligohydramnios(Option B): Reduced amniotic fluid volume because the ageing placenta may become less efficient at supporting the baby, leading to decreased urine output from the fetus and thus reduced amniotic fluid.

Placental Calcifications (Option C): It is also a common finding seen in post-dated pregnancy.

Meconium-stained amniotic fluid (Option D): As the fetus matures and stays longer in the womb, the baby is more likely to pass meconium (the first stool) into the amniotic fluid.

Other findings:

  • Length is about 54 cm.
  • Ageing of placenta with excessive infarction.
  • Diminished quantity of Wharton’s jelly
  • Umbilical cord compression
  • Post maturity syndrome
  • Hypoxia ischaemic encephalopathy
  • placental calcifications

questions.text: A primigravida 42 weeks of gestation comes to the ER with labour pain. She is at increased risk of all of the following complications except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polyhydramnios

Explanation:

Polyhydramnios is a pregnancy complication that can lead to preterm labour.

In post-term pregnancies, an ageing placenta might not function as efficiently, potentially leading to decreased amniotic fluid volume. Oligohydramnios is associated with abnormal fetal heart rate monitoring, umbilical cord compression, and meconium-stained amniotic fluid (Option B,C, and D)

Definition:

  • Any pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery is called post-maturity or post-term pregnancy (or)
  • Pregnancy continuing beyond 42 weeks (greater than 294 days)

Aetiology

  • Wrong dates (Most common)
  • Biological variability (hereditary)
  • Primiparity/ previous prolonged deliveries/Elderly multiparae (maternal factors)
  • Sedentary habits
  • Congenital anomalies (fetal factors)
  • Sulphatase deficiency (placental factors)

Complications of post-term pregnancy:

During labour

After birth
  • Fetal hypoxia / Acidosis
  • Meconium Aspiration
  • Cord compression (Option C)
  • Shoulder dystocia.
  • Increased incidence of operative delivery
  • Chemical pneumonitis due to meconium aspiration
  • Нурохia
  • Hypoglycemia/polycythemia
  • Nicu admissions are increased

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the ER with a fever of 100.8°F and complains of lower abdominal pain. On examination, her membranes are ruptured, and she is in active labour. The attending physician suspects chorioamnionitis. The best-suited management for this patient is?

choices.text: Administer antibiotics and observe for improvement before considering delivery.
Induce labour with oxytocin and administer antibiotics simultaneously.
Immediate cesarean section without administering antibiotics.
Administer antibiotics and prepare for immediate delivery, either vaginal or cesarean.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Administer antibiotics and prepare for immediate delivery, either vaginal or cesarean.

Explanation:

Administer antibiotics and prepare for immediate delivery, either vaginal or cesarean.

  • Chorioamnionitis in PPROM needs urgent treatment to prevent complications.

  • Prompt vaginal delivery and antibiotics are essential.

  • Inflammation is risky even without bacteria, especially in early preterm labour.

  • In preterm births, infection often causes labour; in term births, it follows labour.

  • Fever ≥38°C is the most reliable diagnostic sign; leukocytosis is unreliable.

  • Increases risks of sepsis, respiratory distress, seizures, IVH, PVL, and cerebral palsy

Administer antibiotics and observe for improvement before considering delivery (Option A): This is wrong since delaying delivery increases risks for both mother and fetus 

 

Induce labour with oxytocin and administer antibiotics simultaneously (Option B): This is wrong since the patient is already in active labour, making induction unnecessary 

 

Immediate cesarean section without administering antibiotics (Option C) : Wrong since the cesarean should be reserved for when vaginal delivery is not feasible, and antibiotics are crucial to manage the infection

questions.text: A pregnant female at 14 weeks of gestation comes to the OPD for routine examination. On a pervaginal examination, there is a 2 cm dilation of the cervix. She also has a previous similar history of mid-trimester spontaneous abortion. You planned to do cervical cerclage. All are contraindications except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intact membrane

Explanation

An intact membrane is not a contraindication but rather a requirement for cerclage.

Contraindications of Cerclage:

  1. Intrauterine infection (Option A)
  2. Ruptured Membranes
  3. Presence of vaginal bleeding
  4. Severe uterine irritability
  5. Cervical dilation > 4cm.
  6. Fetal death,Anencephaly (Option B/D)

Types of cerclage: Shirodkar and McDonald

Removal of stitch: 37 weeks or earlier if labour pain starts

Time of Cerclage done:

  1. Prophylactic cerclage is done at 14 weeks of gestation
  2. Emergency cerclage can be done when the cervix is dilated, and the membranes are bulging.

questions.text: A patient presents with slow leak of watery vaginal discharge at 36 weeks of gestation. There is no history of trauma. The PH of the fluid turns out to be 7 and turns the Nitrazine paper from yellow to blue. What is the likely aetiology of the above scenario except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oligohydramnios

Explanation:

Oligohydramnios is a consequence of PROM and not a aetiology

The above scenario suggests premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Definition: Spontaneous membrane rupture any time beyond the 28th week of pregnancy but before the onset of labour is called PROM.

Term PROM Rupture occurs > 37 Weeks but before the onset of labour.

Preterm PROM occurs < 37 weeks

Prolonged rupture = Rupture of the membrane 24 hours before delivery

Aetiology:

  • Previous history of PTL (preterm labour ) (Opinion C)
  • Pregnancy followed by ART(Assisted reproductive technique)
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria / recent UTI (Option D)
  • Smoking
  • Low Socioeconomic Status
  • Maternal Stress
  • regnancy-related complication
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • APH ( Antepartum hemorrhagic)
  • Polyhydramnios (Option B)
  • Uterine Anomalies
  • Chronic diseases like HTN and DM
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Iatrogenic
  • Idiopathic

Confirmation of diagnosis:

  • Per speculum examination: Under aseptic Conditions
  • To examine the collected fluid from the posterior fornix for PH by litmus/ Nitrazine paper (Yellow to blue)
  • Smear made from the fluid shows ferning
  • Centrifuged cells stained 0.1% Nile blue sulfate show orange blue colouration of cells
  • AmniSure is a rapid immuno assay. It is accurate
  • USG - to support the diagnosis and to assess the fetal well-being.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of tocolysis except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pregnancy 31 weeks of gestation

Explanation

Tocolysis aims to delay delivery, typically to allow time for interventions like corticosteroid therapy or transfer to a facility with a higher level of neonatal care.

Contraindications of tocolysis

  • Fetal distress (Option A)
  • Fetal death
  • Congenital Malformation (Option C)
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks Rupture of membranes
  • Chorioamniotitis (Option B)
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Cervical dilation 4cm

questions.text: What is the definition of early preterm labour according to ACOG guidelines?

choices.text: Labour that occurs before 24 weeks of gestation.
Labour that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.
Labour that occurs between 32 and <37 weeks of gestation.
Labour that occurs between 34 and 36 weeks of gestation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Labour that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

Early preterm labour is defined as labour that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.

Term

Definition according to (ACOG)

Preterm

Birth before 37 weeks of gestation
  • Early Preterm

Birth before 34 weeks of gestation
  • Late Preterm (Option D)

Birth between 34 and 36+6 weeks of gestation

Full Term

Birth between 39 and 40+6 weeks of gestation

Early Term

Birth between 37 and 38+6 weeks of gestation

Postterm

Birth at 42 weeks of gestation or later

 

Term

Definition according to WHO

Extremely Preterm (Option A)

Birth before 28 completed weeks of gestation

Very Preterm

Birth from 28 to less than 32 completed weeks

Moderate to Late Preterm (Option C)

Birth from 32 to less than 37 completed weeks

Full Term

Birth from 37 to less than 42 completed weeks

Postterm

Birth at 42 completed weeks of gestation or later

questions.text: To confirm lung maturity, how much fetal RBCs should be orange?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) >50%

Explanation:

  • To assess fetal lung maturity, amniotic fluid is collected and centrifuged to isolate desquamated fetal epithelial cells.
  • These cells are then stained using 0.1% Nile blue sulfate, a supravital dye.
  • Nile blue stains keratinized cells—which increase as fetal lungs mature—into an orange color, while non-keratinized cells remain blue or green.
  • The presence of keratinized (orange-stained) cells reflects increased production of surfactant, which is essential for lung maturity.
  • If more than 50% of the fetal cells stain orange, this is considered a reliable indicator of fetal lung maturity.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing fetal pulmonary maturity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bilirubin in amniotic fluid

Explanation:

Respiratory distress syndrome risk is high in preterm infants, it is caused by pulmonary surfactant deficiency.

The tests to access pulmonary maturity are done in amniotic fluid.

Assessment Method

Description

Lecithin/Sphingomyelin (L/S) Ratio (estimation of pulmonary surfactant)

L/S ratio of 1 at 31-32 weeks, 2 at 35 weeks, and >2.2 indicates pulmonary maturity

Shake/Clement's/bubble Test

Amniotic fluid is mixed with ethanol; stable foam formation indicates pulmonary maturity

Foam Stability Index (FSI)

Quantitative measure of surfactant presence using serial dilutions; FSI of 47 virtually excludes RDS

Presence of Phosphatidylglycerol (PG)

Detectable by thin-layer chromatography; presence indicates lung maturation

Saturated phosphatidylcholine

500 ng/mL or more indicates maturity

Fluorescence Polarization

Measures surfactant to albumin ratio; presence of 55 mg/g surfactant indicates lung maturity

Amniotic Fluid Optical Density at 650 nm

Optical density >0.15 indicates lung maturity

Lamellar Body Count

Count >30,000/µl indicates pulmonary maturity

Orange Colored Cells (Nile Blue Sulfate Stain)

Presence of >50% orange-colored cells suggests pulmonary maturity

Amniotic Fluid Turbidity

Becomes turbid at term due to vernix; not directly used as a primary marker for maturity

questions.text: A 32-year-old female, G3 P2 L2 with h/o two spontaneous early preterm births is seen in routine antenatal OPD. Which of the following can prevent her risk of spontaneous preterm birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Progesterone

Explanation:

Progesterone is used to reduce the risk of spontaneous preterm labour and birth.

  • It contributes to pregnancy maintenance via the corpus luteum and placental production.
  • It maintains uterine quiescence and modulates immune responses to counteract pro-inflammatory pathways.
  • Progesterone is not tocolytic, so used in prophylaxis .

questions.text: A 32-year-old female G2 P1 presented with a history of preterm delivery in the previous pregnancy, resulting in the child presenting with cerebral palsy. Which of the following has a neuroprotective role for the fetus in cases of extreme prematurity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Magnesium sulfate

Explanation:

  • Magnesium sulfate is recommended for neuroprotection in cases of imminent preterm birth, specifically between 24 and 32 weeks of gestation.
  • Magnesium sulfate is given as a 6-g bolus over 20 to 30 minutes and is followed with a maintenance infusion of 2 g/hr.

 

Nifedipine, Glyceryl trinitrate, Indomethacin, they have tocolytic properties but not neuroprotective (Option A, B, C)

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation presents with regular uterine contractions every 5 minutes associated with mild lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, her cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows no signs of distress. Which of the following is the tocolytic of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nifedipine

Explanation:

Nifedipine is the first-line tocolytic.

Tocolytics are used to prevent uterine contractions. It can be used for short or long-term therapy.

Tocolytics in preterm labour:

Objective
  • To delay delivery at least 48 hours for glucocorticoid therapy (for fetal lung maturation)

C/I
  • Maternal
    • Uncontrolled diabetes, thyrotoxicosis, severe hypertension, cardiac disease, haemorrhage in pregnancy.
  • Fetal
    • Fetal distress, fetal death, congenital malformation, pregnancy beyond 34 weeks
  • Others
    • Rupture of membranes, chorioamnionitis, cervical dilation of more than 4 cm

Drugs
  • Calcium channel blockers
    • Nifedipine, Nicardipine, Verapamil
  • Magnesium sulfate
  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
  • Betamimetics
    • Terbutaline, Ritodrine, Isoxsuprine
  • Atosiban
  • Glyceryl trinitrate

 

Atociban (option B): it's expensive and used when CCBand beta adrengic agonists  isn't used in heart conditions

 Indomethacin (option C): not used beyond 32 weeks of gestation because it can cause premature closure of DA

 Nitric oxide (option D): not used in clinical practice

questions.text: A pregnant female at 32 weeks gestation presents with signs of preterm labour. To promote fetal lung maturity, which medications and doses should be administered?

choices.text: Betamethasone 12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours
Dexamethasone 6 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours
Prednisolone 20 mg PO daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Betamethasone 12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours

Explanation:

Betamethasone is a corticosteroid used to enhance fetal lung maturity in preterm labour. It is administered in two doses, 12 mg IM each, 24 hours apart, to stimulate fetal lung maturation and reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome.

Corticosteroid therapy  used for fetal lung maturity in preterm labour

Corticosteroid

Dosage and Administration

Mechanism of Action

Betamethasone (Preferred choice)

12 mg IM, repeated after 24 hours (2 doses)

Enhances fetal lung maturation by stimulating surfactant production

Dexamethasone (Alternative)

6 mg IM, repeated every 12 hours (4 doses)

Similar mechanism to betamethasone

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, at 32 weeks gestation, presents to the emergency department with complaints of regular uterine contractions every 10 minutes and lower back pain. She denies any leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Upon examination, her cervix is found to be 3 cm dilated and 80% effaced. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a reactive pattern. Which of the following complications is not anticipated in this patient with preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Duodenal atresia

Explanation:

  • Regular uterine contractions and lower back pain are signs of labor.
  • A gestational age 32 weeks points towards preterm labor; term labor would occur between 37 and 42 weeks.
  • The cervix is described as being 3 cm dilated and 80% effaced at 32 weeks, indicating preterm labour.
  • She denies leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding, ruling out premature rupture of membranes or other complications that will be confused with labor

Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition in which part of the duodenum is blocked or missing. While it can occur in newborns, it's not directly associated with preterm labour.

Fetal Complications

Maternal Complications
  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS)
  • Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia (BPD)
  • Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH)
  • Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP)
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • Pneumonia/sepsis
  • Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL)
  • Cerebral palsy (CP)
  • Neurodevelopmental Impairment
  • Postpartum Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Psychological Impact
  • Increased Cesarean Delivery Rates
  • Complications from Prolonged Bed Rest

questions.text: A 28-year-old primi at 30 weeks gestation presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain and backache. She has no significant medical history. On examination, her cervix is closed, but there are mild irregular uterine contractions. The obstetrician plans to measure fetal fibronectin (fFN) to assess the risk of preterm labour. Which of the following statements about fetal fibronectin (fFN) is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a glycoprotein at the interface of the chorion and the decidua.
Functions as adhesive glue between the fetal membranes and decidua.
Testing is typically performed between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation.
A negative test is highly predictive of delivery within the next 7 days.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A negative test is highly predictive of delivery within the next 7 days.

Explanation:

Fetal Fibronectin (fFN):

Origin

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced by fetal cells.

Found at the interface of the chorion and the decidua 

Mechanism
  • Function in intercellular adhesion during implantation.
  • Normally present in cervical and vaginal secretions in early pregnancy and again in late pregnancy, typically not found between 22 and 34 weeks.
  • Disruption of this "glue" (due to inflammation, infection, or physical disruption) releases fFN into the cervicovaginal secretions.

Uses

Measurement of fFN levels in cervicovaginal secretions can help predict the risk of preterm birth. Recommended for symptomatic women between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation.

  • Positive Result: Indicates a higher risk of preterm birth, but it is not definitive.
  • Negative Result: Suggests a low risk of preterm birth within the next 7-14 days.

Limitations
  • Positive results do not guarantee preterm labour
  • Recent sexual activity, vaginal examination, or the presence of lubricants or disinfectants can affect test accuracy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Obesity

Explanation:

Obesity is not a well-established risk factor for preterm labour.

Risk factors for preterm labour:

  • Previous Preterm Birth
  • Multiple Gestation (Twins)
  • Uterine or Cervical Anomalies
  • Maternal Age (Being under 17 or over 35 years old)
  • Short Interpregnancy Interval
  • Infections (Bacterial vaginosis, urinary tract infections)
  • Chronic diseases [Diabetes, high blood pressure (preeclampsia)]
  • Smoking and Substance Use
  • Stress and Psychological Factors
  • Low Socioeconomic Status
  • Poor Nutritional Status
  • Previous Pregnancy Complications (History of placenta previa, placental abruption)
